VulnerabilityDesc.Type: Missing events for critical parameter changing operations by owner
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The owner of the contract can change critical parameters without emitting events, leading to loss of funds/confidence and reputational hit.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Emit events when critical addresses/values are updated

VulnerabilityDesc.Type: Malicious owner can arbitrarily change fee to any % value
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Malicious owner can change fees without any event or timelock, leading to loss of funds/confidence and reputational hit.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Implement Emit event and provide timelock for users to react and establish upper threshold for fees

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The ownership of this contract is transferred to governance address in the constructor. This critical address transfer in one-step is very risky because it is irrecoverable from any mistakes.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Use a two-step address change to governance address separately using setter functions

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The smart contract doesn't check the return value of token.transfer() and token.transferFrom(), some erc20 token might not revert in case of error but return false.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Wrap the call into a require() or use openzeppelin's SafeERC20 library

VulnerabilityDesc.Location: deposit() functions of Insurance and TracerPerpetualSwaps
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Assuming external ERC20 balance increases by the same amount as amount parameter of transferFrom can lead to avoiding taxes and loss of funds.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Measure asset change before and after asset-transferring functions

VulnerabilityDesc.Type: Malicious owner can drain the market at any time using SafetyWithdraw
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Malicious owner can withdraw all tracerQuoteTokens deposited, leading to loss of funds/confidence and reputational hit.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Design a pause/unpause feature where deposits are paused (in emergency situations) but withdrawals are allowed by the depositors themselves instead of the owner

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: It is possible to avoid paying insurance by manipulating the system, leading to loss of funds and grief attack.

VulnerabilityDesc.Type: Insurance slippage reimbursement can be used to steal insurance fund
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: An attacker can abuse the system to make a profit by liquidating themselves and repeatedly submitting bad trades for slippage reimbursement, leading to draining of insurance fund.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Disallow duplicate orders in the orders argument of claimReceipt()

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: An agent can manipulate trading prices by spamming a high amount of trades, leading to manipulation of the market.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Pass fillAmount parameter to recordTrade() and calculate hourlyTracerPrices[currentHour].trades summing fillAmount instead of 1 every trade

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: It might be possible for first-time depositors to skip having to pay the first funding rate period as the accountLastUpdatedIndex + 1 < currentGlobalFundingIndex check will still return false when the funding rates are updated the next time.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Check if setting it to currentGlobalFundingIndex or to currentGlobalFundingIndex 1 is correct

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Reentrancy could happen in the executeTrade function of Trader since the makeOrder.market can be a user-controlled external contract.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Add a reentrancy guard to prevent users from reentering critical functions

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The current design allows for a griefing attack where an attacker can deny any other user from trading by observing the mempool and front-running their trades by creating their own order and match it against the counter order instead.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Maintain an off-chain order book that is the entry point for users to make orders and for market makers to interact with

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The scaling depends on the underlying decimals of the two oracles and could be anything. If the scale is wrong, the gas price can be heavily inflated or under-reported.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Check chainlink.decimals() to know the decimals of the oracle answers and scale the answers to 18 decimals

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The contracts assume that all tokens will have <=18 decimals. The scaler computations will underflow and be defined when it should not be.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Write a require check that ensures tokenDecimals <= 18 before running the above functions

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The current code subtracts a fee from the short position and adds it to the long. The correct implementation is to subtract a fee to both.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Change +fee to -fee in the highlighted line

VulnerabilityDesc.Location: executeTrade function in Trader.sol and claimReceipt function in Liquidation.sol
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: A liquidator can claim the liquidation escrow by creating a second account, setting up a complimentary trade resulting in a large slippage, executing the trade between their own two accounts, and calling claimReceipt with the receiptId of the executed order within the required period.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Limit who can call executeTrade function
